app_metadata.title: Disaster Response First Aid & Survival Guide
sources: WHO Emergency First Aid & ETAT Guidelines
St John Ambulance First Aid Reference
app_metadata.disclaimer: This app is designed for educational guidance only and is not a substitute for professional first aid training or emergency medical services. In case of life-threatening emergency, always contact emergency services (112 or local equivalent) immediately. Users provide first aid at their own risk based on their training level.

steps.details: Move away from danger if needed; protect yourself first
Use clean cloth or dressing; press firmly on wound; wear gloves if available
Do not remove first cloth; add more cloth/dressing on top if bleeding continues
Raise injured body part above heart level to slow bleeding
Contact 112 or local equivalent immediately

do_not: Release pressure to look at wound
Use tourniquet (unless trained and bleeding uncontrollable)
danger_signs_escalate: Bleeding does not stop after 10 minutes of direct pressure
Wound is deep, gaping, or on face/hands
Signs of shock present (cold, clammy skin; rapid weak pulse; weakness)
severe_bleeding.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately; continue pressure while waiting for help
severe_bleeding.source: IFRC 2020, Red Cross, St John Ambulance

recognition: Person does not respond to voice or touch
Eyes may be open or closed
Breathing may be present or absent

steps.details: Ensure area is safe to approach
Shout person's name; tap shoulders gently; allow max 10 seconds for response
If unresponsive, immediately get 112
Gently tilt head back, lift chin (unless neck injury suspected)
Listen and feel for breath for maximum 10 seconds
If breathing normally, turn onto side to keep airway open; see recovery position section

do: Place in recovery position if breathing
Be ready to perform CPR if needed
do_not: Move neck or spine if trauma suspected
danger_signs_escalate: No response to voice or touch
unconscious_person.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately; prepare to perform CPR if not breathing

recognition: Unresponsive AND not breathing normally (agonal gasping does NOT count)

steps.details: Check for danger to yourself and person
Call 112 immediately; use speakerphone if alone with person
Lay on back on firm surface
Place heel of hand on center of chest; place other hand on top; interlock fingers; push hard and fast 5-6cm deep at rate of 100-120 compressions per minute; perform 30 compressions
If willing and trained: tilt head back, pinch nose, seal mouth with yours; give 2 breaths watching chest rise. If unwilling or unable: compression-only CPR is acceptable and effective
Continue 30 compressions : 2 breaths pattern until professional help takes over, person wakes up, you become exhausted, or AED available

do_not: Give rescue breaths without chest compressions
Perform CPR on a person who is breathing normally
cpr_adult.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately; perform CPR continuously until help arrives
cpr_adult.source: IFRC 2020, Red Cross, UK Resuscitation Council

steps.details: Ask 'Are you choking?'; if nodding, act immediately
If person can cough/speak, allow them to cough; don't intervene
Bend person forward at waist; give 5 sharp blows between shoulder blades with heel of hand
Stand behind person; wrap arms around abdomen above navel; perform quick upward thrusts
Continue alternating 5 back blows and 5 thrusts until object comes out or person becomes unresponsive

do: Encourage coughing if person can cough
Use back blows and abdominal thrusts
Get emergency help if not resolved quickly
do_not: Perform thrusts if person can still cough/speak
Perform CPR unless person becomes unconscious
danger_signs_escalate: Complete inability to breathe or speak
choking.escalation_action: If person becomes unresponsive, call 112 and begin CPR

steps.details: Stop bleeding, cover burns, handle injuries
Position on back with head level
Raise legs about 30cm (unless leg/pelvis fracture, then keep flat)
Cover with blanket; avoid direct heat
Contact 112 immediately; do not leave alone

shock.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately; continue care while waiting for help
shock.source: IFRC 2020, St John Ambulance, Red Cross

recognition: Partial thickness: Red/raw, blistered, extremely painful
Full thickness: Charred, white, painless (nerve damage)

steps.details: Run cool (NOT cold) water over burn for 20+ minutes; remove jewelry and tight clothing while cooling
If fabric stuck, leave it; work around it
Leave intact to prevent infection
Use clean plastic film or sterile dressing
For burns larger than person's palm, on face/hands/genitals, or deep burns

do: Seek medical help for serious burns
Give water to drink if conscious
danger_signs_escalate: Burns larger than 1% of body (about person's palm)
Burns on face, hands, feet, or genitals
burns.escalation_action: Call 112 for all serious burns; continue cooling while waiting
burns.source: St John Ambulance, IFRC 2020, Red Cross

steps.details: Immobilize injured part immediately
Wrap ice in cloth; apply to reduce swelling (if available)
Raise limb above heart level if possible
Use sling, cushions, or tape to keep immobilized
Seek X-ray and professional evaluation

do_not: Give food or drink (surgery may be needed)
fractures.escalation_action: Call 112 for open fractures or serious injuries; immobilize and elevate while waiting

steps.details: Do not move head or neck; assume spine injury
Apply light pressure with clean cloth (do not press hard)
Slightly raise head with support
Watch for changes in consciousness and breathing
If unconscious, vomiting, or worsening confusion, call 112

do_not: Move head or spine if trauma suspected
Apply pressure to wounds with fluid
Give food or drink if unconscious
danger_signs_escalate: Clear fluid from nose or ear
head_injury.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately for any loss of consciousness or warning signs

steps.details: Get away from animal to prevent further bites
Gently wash with soap and water
Immobilize bitten limb (movement spreads venom)
Take off rings and bracelets (swelling may occur)
Seek medical attention; antivenom may be needed

do: Wash wound with soap and water
do_not: Attempt to catch or kill animal
danger_signs_escalate: Systemic symptoms (nausea, breathing difficulty, numbness spreading)
snake_bite.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately; antivenom may be required

recognition: HOT DRY SKIN (not sweating) - this is critical

steps.details: Get out of sun and heat immediately
Allow cooling
Use wet sheets, cold sponging, fan, or cool water spray - aggressive cooling
Contact 112 immediately
Until temperature drops or professional arrives

do: Move to shade or cool area

recognition: Late stage: Shivering stops; cold, pale, dry skin; confusion; slurred speech; drowsiness; slow breathing and pulse; risk of cardiac arrest

steps.details: Get out of cold/wet environment
Gently (aggressive movement can cause cardiac arrest)
Wrap in blankets, sleeping bag, or emergency blanket
Heat loss through head is significant
Seek professional assessment even if appears recovered

do: Give warm (not hot) drinks if conscious
do_not: Apply direct heat or hot water
Assume person is dead (rewarm fully first)
hypothermia.escalation_action: Call 112 for severe hypothermia; gentle rewarming important

recognition: Unresponsive in or out of water
Gasping or no breathing when pulled out

steps.details: Safely remove from water (do not endanger yourself; don't enter if can't swim)
Tap, shout, assess
Contact 112 immediately
Maximum 10 seconds
For drowning: give 5 initial rescue breaths first, then 30:2 pattern

do: Place in recovery position if breathing
do_not: Assume person is fine after rescue
danger_signs_escalate: Any coughing/wheezing later (secondary drowning can occur hours later)
drowning.escalation_action: Call 112 immediately; perform CPR if needed

before: Identify safe spots at home and work (under sturdy table, against interior wall)
Practice 'Drop, Cover, Hold On' with family
Secure heavy furniture to walls
Know how to turn off gas and electricity
Prepare emergency kit with water, food, first aid
during: Indoors: Drop to hands and knees → Cover head/neck under sturdy table → Hold on until shaking stops
Outdoors: Move away from buildings, power lines, and trees
In vehicle: Stay inside; move away from power lines and overpasses
Trapped: Do not shout; tap on pipe or wall to signal rescuers
after: Check for injuries and provide first aid
Check for hazards (gas leak, electrical damage, structural damage)
If smell gas: turn off gas at meter outside
If see sparks: turn off electricity at main breaker
Exit building using stairs (not elevators); check for structural damage
do: Drop, cover, hold on during shaking
do_not: Run outside during shaking (falling debris danger)

before: Know evacuation routes and high ground locations
Keep important documents in waterproof container
Have emergency kit ready
Know location of high ground near home
during: If ordered to evacuate: Leave immediately; do not delay
If trapped in building: Go to highest floor or roof; signal for help
If in vehicle: Do not drive through floodwater; turn around (6 inches can knock person over; 12 inches can sweep car away)
after: Check for structural damage and electrical hazards

before: Plan escape route from each room
Practice evacuation plan with family
Install and test smoke detectors
Keep fire extinguisher accessible
Know location of exits
during: Get out fast - leave immediately if fire or smoke detected
Close doors - slows spread of fire and smoke
Stay low - crawl under smoke (fresher air near floor)
Don't stop - do not hide or collect valuables
Use stairs - never use elevators
after: Contact emergency services if not already done

before: Identify safe room (interior room, lowest level, away from windows)
Secure outdoor items (furniture, trash cans, branches)
Prepare emergency kit
Know evacuation routes
during: Go to safe room - interior room on lowest floor, away from windows
Stay inside - do not go outside
Get under sturdy object - table, mattress for protection
Protect head/neck - use pillows and blankets
Stay until all clear - do not leave until weather improves significantly
after: Check for injuries and provide first aid
Look for hazards (downed power lines, debris, structural damage)

before: Know if in landslide-prone area
Have evacuation plan
Know warning signs: unusual animal behavior, cracked ground, springs appearing, trees tilting
during: Evacuate if signs of landslide appear
Move perpendicular - move at right angle to slide direction (not downslope)
Get to high ground - away from slide path
Call for help - alert emergency services if hazard near populated area
after: Check for new cracks or hazards

steps.details: High, dry ground; away from hazards (dead trees, unstable slopes)
Rock overhangs, dense trees, existing buildings if safe
Use plastic sheeting, tarps, cardboard, branches; create barrier; angle to shed rain
Pile leaves, cardboard, blankets under shelter
Leave small opening if heating with fire (prevent carbon monoxide)

do_not: Use plastic sheeting without ventilation in enclosed space
Close off completely if using fire for heat

safe_water.purpose: Access to safe water is life-sustaining; contaminated water causes diarrhea and disease

steps.details: Sealed containers are safest option

steps.action: Boil water if no bottled water
steps.details: Bring to rolling boil for at least 1 minute; cool before drinking; store in clean covered container
Add 6 drops household bleach (unscented) per gallon; wait 30 minutes before drinking. Or use water purification tablets per package instructions

steps.action: Filter first if water is cloudy
steps.details: Filter through cloth to remove particles; then boil or disinfect
Use sealed containers in cool dark place; cover to prevent contamination and mosquito breeding

food_safety.purpose: When refrigeration is lost, food safety depends on temperature and time

steps.details: Eat refrigerated food before it spoils; food at 40°F/4°C or below is safe
Discard if above 40°F for more than 2 hours, or if meat/fish smells off or is slimy
Canned goods, crackers, nuts, dried fruit, peanut butter, cereals
Wash hands before eating; use clean utensils; cook food thoroughly if possible
Anything moldy, from dented/leaking cans, or from damaged containers

hygiene_sanitation.purpose: Good hygiene prevents disease transmission; most effective intervention is hand washing

steps.details: After toilet, before eating/cooking, after touching wounds. Wet hands, use soap, scrub all surfaces 20+ seconds, rinse, air dry
Use ash, sand, or soil for scrubbing; rinse with minimal water; allow air dry
Use latrine if available; otherwise designate area away from water and living space; bury waste 30+ cm deep
Bury/burn garbage away from shelter; keep food waste in covered container; don't let animals access waste
Don't share cups/utensils; cover coughs/sneezes; isolate ill persons if possible; avoid touching face/eyes

do: Wash hands frequently (20+ seconds with soap)

contacts.service: Flood / Rain Emergency Help (Greater Chennai Corporation)

legal_disclaimers.general_disclaimer: This information is not a substitute for professional first aid training or medical care. In case of life-threatening emergency, always call emergency services (112 or local equivalent) immediately. First aid should be provided only to the level of training received. These guidelines are for educational purposes for non-medical civilians to support emergency response.
legal_disclaimers.offline_limitation: This app is designed for offline emergency guidance only. In areas with cellular or radio coverage, immediately contact emergency services for professional medical help.
legal_disclaimers.training_recommendation: For best results, users should complete formal first aid training with a recognized organization (Red Cross, St John Ambulance, etc.). This app supplements, not replaces, such training.
legal_disclaimers.liability_protection: Users provide first aid at their own risk. This app is provided for educational guidance; users assume responsibility for decisions and outcomes. This content is based on authoritative sources but may not cover all situations or local variations.
legal_disclaimers.escalation_emphasis: When in doubt, seek professional medical help. Contact emergency services for any life-threatening condition.
legal_disclaimers.medical_limitation: No diagnosis: This app does not provide medical diagnosis. No medications: This app does not include medication names or dosages. No advanced procedures: This app describes basic first aid only.
legal_disclaimers.sources_transparency: All content sourced from authoritative organizations: IFRC, WHO, Red Cross, St John Ambulance, FEMA, Resuscitation Council. Content paraphrased to avoid verbatim copying; suitable for educational use.
legal_disclaimers.version_note: These guidelines are current as of January 2026 based on 2020 authoritative standards. Medical guidance evolves; consult current official sources for updates.
legal_disclaimers.accessibility_note: This app is designed for offline use in disaster/emergency situations without internet access. For comprehensive information, visit official organization websites.
